Classic Cranberry Sauce

Jump to Recipe

Welcome to the ultimate guide on how to make Classic Cranberry Sauce, a must-have side dish for your holiday feasts! This recipe captures the vibrant flavors of fresh cranberries, perfectly balanced with sweetness and a hint of citrus, making it the ideal complement to your Thanksgiving turkey or Christmas ham. With just a handful of ingredients — fresh cranberries, granulated sugar, water, and aromatic spices — you can create a delightful homemade sauce that outshines any store-bought version. Not only is this recipe simple and quick, but it also allows you to customize flavors with the addition of orange zest and a touch of cinnamon. Whether you're a seasoned chef or a beginner in the kitchen, this Classic Cranberry Sauce recipe will impress your family and friends, ensuring that your holiday gatherings are filled with deliciousness!

Ingredients

fresh cranberries

Choose firm, plump cranberries that are deep red in color. If you can't find fresh cranberries, you can substitute with frozen cranberries; just do not thaw them before use. Fresh cranberries can also be blanched for a few minutes to enhance their tartness.

granulated sugar

Regular granulated sugar works best, but you can substitute with brown sugar for a deeper flavor or honey/maple syrup for a natural sweetener, keeping in mind that these may change the consistency slightly. Adjust the quantity according to your preferred sweetness.

water

Use filtered water for a cleaner taste, but tap water is also fine. If you want to add depth, consider using orange juice or apple juice instead of water, which will complement the flavors.

orange zest

Freshly grated orange zest will provide the best flavor. If you don't have an orange, you can substitute with lemon zest for a different citrus note, or use a few drops of orange extract, but reduce the quantity since extracts are more concentrated.

cinnamon stick

Cinnamon sticks add a warm, aromatic quality; if you don’t have them, you can use 1/2 teaspoon of ground cinnamon instead. However, add it towards the end of cooking to avoid bitterness, as ground spices can become overpowering.

salt

A pinch of salt enhances the overall flavor, balancing the sweetness. If you want to elevate the flavor further, consider using sea salt or adding a touch of kosher salt for a more nuanced taste.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Prepare the Cranberries

    Rinse the fresh cranberries under cold water to remove any dirt or debris. Inspect the cranberries carefully and remove any stems or damaged berries. It's essential to use only fresh, plump cranberries for the best flavor.

  • Step 2: Combine Water and Sugar

    In a medium-sized saucepan, combine 1 cup of water with 1 cup of granulated sugar. Place the saucepan over medium heat and bring the mixture to a boil. Stir occasionally to help dissolve the sugar completely.

  • Step 3: Add Cranberries

    Once the sugar and water mixture is boiling, add the rinsed cranberries to the saucepan. Stir gently to combine, and allow the mixture to return to a boil.

  • Step 4: Simmer the Sauce

    After the mixture is boiling again, reduce the heat to low and let it simmer for about 10-15 minutes. You will notice the cranberries starting to burst, which is a sign that the sauce is thickening. Stir occasionally to prevent sticking.

  • Step 5: Add Flavorings

    Once the cranberries have burst and the sauce has thickened to your liking, stir in 1 teaspoon of orange zest, a cinnamon stick, and a pinch of salt. The orange zest adds a lovely citrus aroma, while the cinnamon enhances the overall flavor.

  • Step 6: Cool and Store

    Remove the saucepan from heat and let the cranberry sauce cool to room temperature. Once cooled, transfer the sauce to an airtight container and refrigerate. The flavors will meld beautifully as it chills.

Frequently Asked Questions

How do I rinse and prepare fresh cranberries?

To rinse fresh cranberries, place them in a colander and run cold water over them. Gently shake the colander to remove any debris. Look for any stems or damaged berries and remove them before cooking.

What does it mean to bring a mixture to a boil?

Bringing a mixture to a boil means heating it until large bubbles break the surface continuously. For your cranberry sauce, you want to see vigorous bubbling after adding the sugar and water.

How do I know when the cranberries are done cooking?

The cranberries are done when they have burst and the sauce has thickened, which usually takes about 10-15 minutes of simmering. You'll hear popping sounds as the berries burst.

Why do I need to add salt to the sauce?

A pinch of salt helps to enhance the flavors of the sauce, balancing the sweetness of the sugar and the tartness of the cranberries.

Can I adjust the sweetness of the cranberry sauce?

Yes! If you prefer a less sweet sauce, you can reduce the amount of sugar. Start with 3/4 cup and taste as you go.

How should I store leftover cranberry sauce?

Once the sauce has cooled to room temperature, transfer it to an airtight container and refrigerate. It can last for up to two weeks in the fridge.

What can I do with leftover cranberry sauce?

Leftover cranberry sauce can be used in various ways: spread it on sandwiches, blend it into smoothies, or use it as a topping for yogurt or desserts.

Can I make cranberry sauce ahead of time?

Absolutely! Cranberry sauce can be made up to a week in advance. Just store it in the refrigerator until you’re ready to serve.

What if I don't have a cinnamon stick?

If you don’t have a cinnamon stick, you can use 1/4 teaspoon of ground cinnamon instead. Just stir it in after the sauce has finished cooking.

How can I make my cranberry sauce more flavorful?

You can add other spices like nutmeg or ginger, or include a splash of orange juice or apple cider for extra flavor. Experiment to find the taste you love!

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

This Classic Cranberry Sauce is naturally gluten-free and vegan, making it suitable for a variety of dietary preferences. For a lower-sugar option, substitute granulated sugar with a sugar alternative like agave syrup or honey, adjusting the quantity to taste. For those avoiding sugar altogether, consider a stevia-based sweetener as an alternative.

Pairings

Classic Cranberry Sauce pairs beautifully with roasted turkey, ham, or pork, adding a vibrant tartness that complements the savory flavors of these meats. For beverages, consider serving with a crisp white wine like Sauvignon Blanc or a fruity red like Pinot Noir. A sparkling cider also makes a festive non-alcoholic option, enhancing the celebratory feel of the dish.

Serving Suggestions

Serve the cranberry sauce chilled or at room temperature in a decorative bowl. Garnish with a sprig of fresh mint or a few whole cranberries for a festive touch. For an elevated presentation, consider pairing it with a cheese platter featuring creamy cheeses like Brie or goat cheese to contrast the tartness of the sauce. It also works well as a topping for roasted vegetables or as a spread on sandwiches, particularly turkey or ham sandwiches, adding depth and flavor.

Classic Cranberry Sauce

30 min
$3.5
100 kcal
Difficulty: 20%
Servings: 8

Dietary Tags:

VegetarianVeganGluten-Free

Cuisine:

American

Course:

CondimentSide Dish

Tags:

SauceCondimentHoliday

Description

A sweet and tangy cranberry sauce that perfectly complements your holiday meals!

Ingredients

  • fresh cranberries: 12 oz
  • granulated sugar: 1 cup
  • water: 1 cup
  • orange zest: 1 tsp
  • cinnamon stick: 1
  • salt: a pinch
